elements.content: Reaction of a flexible bis-bidentate ligand 1,4-bis(8-thioquinolyl)butane (C4TQ) with silver(I) salts afforded five complexes, namely, [Ag2(C4TQ)2](CF3SO3)2 (1), {[Ag(C4TQ)](CF3SO3)} n ·0.5nCH3CN (2), [Ag2(C4TQ)2](ClO4)2 (3), {[Ag(C4TQ)](ClO4)} n (4), and {[Ag(C4TQ)(CH3CN)](ClO4)} n (5), of which 1 and 3 show dimeric M2L2 metallacycles while 2 and 4 show polymeric M n L n chains. The acetonitrile (MeCN) molecule in complex 2 is located in the crystal lattice without coordination to the Ag(I) ion. Therefore, two pairs of isomerized structures that retain the same compositions, [Ag2(C4TQ)2](CF3SO3)2 vs {[Ag(C4TQ)](CF3SO3)} n in complexes 1 and 2, as well as [Ag2(C4TQ)2](ClO4)2 vs {[Ag(C4TQ)](ClO4)} n in complexes 3 and 4, respectively, can be identified and regarded as ring-opening isomers. 1H NMR and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry studies in solution suggested that the cyclic and infinite structures were assembled from the same monomeric ML building blocks, which crystallized in different forms by dimerization or polymerization during the crystallization. The complex 5 also formed an infinite chain, but the MeCN molecule participated in coordination, indicating that the solvent and/or anion molecules may play a significant role in the assembly process. X-ray diffraction measurements and density functional theory calculations have been performed to track the structural conversion and elucidate the assembly mechanism.

The complex 5 also formed an infinite chain, but the MeCN molecule participated in coordination, indicating that the solvent and/or anion molecules may play a significant role in the assembly process. X-ray diffraction measurements and density functional theory calculations have been performed to track the structural conversion and elucidate the assembly mechanism.

elements.content: Discrete metallacyclic M2L2 and infinite one-dimensional M n L n coordination frameworks were formed from the same ML monomers via a solvent and/or anion assisting assembly process, which was confirmed by solution 1H NMR and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry studies, solid-state X-ray diffraction measurements, and theoretical calculations.
elements.clean_text: Discrete metallacyclic M2L2 and infinite one-dimensional M n L n  coordination frameworks were formed from the same ML monomers via a solvent and/or anion assisting assembly process, which was confirmed by solution 1H NMR and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry studies, solid-state X-ray diffraction measurements, and theoretical calculations.

elements.content: Supramolecular chemistry of silver(I) coordination assemblies is a dynamic, thriving field that has drawn ever increasing research interests during the last few decades. Two major themes, namely, discrete molecular architectures of polyhedral or polygonal shapes and infinite coordination polymers of one-, two- or three-dimensions (1D, 2D, or 3D), have been well developed on the basis of the versatile coordination geometry of Ag(I) ion in combination with the deliberately tailored organic ligands. However, although the same self-assembly approach has been widely applied to supramolecular synthesis of both discrete and infinite structures, not much attention has been paid to the intrinsic relationship between these two topologically distinctive systems. The popular method to analyze complex polymeric structures is to simplify them as “node-and-connector” topological connections, and this topological analysis inspired chemists to assemble coordination polymers from the assumed building blocks (nodes) in a reciprocal way. Such a hypothetical synthesis, in principle, is very helpful to predict and design target coordination frameworks; nevertheless, the details in how the building blocks are polymerized during crystallization remain largely unknown. On the contrary, a number of excellent solution dynamics studies have been carried out to elucidate the assembly processes for discrete molecular architectures.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Supramolecular chemistry of silver(I) coordination assemblies is a dynamic, thriving field that has drawn ever increasing research interests during the last few decades. Two major themes, namely, discrete molecular architectures of polyhedral or polygonal shapes and infinite coordination polymers of one-, two- or three-dimensions (1D, 2D, or 3D), have been well developed on the basis of the versatile coordination geometry of Ag(I) ion in combination with the deliberately tailored organic ligands. However, although the same self-assembly approach has been widely applied to supramolecular synthesis of both discrete and infinite structures, not much attention has been paid to the intrinsic relationship between these two topologically distinctive systems. The popular method to analyze complex polymeric structures is to simplify them as "node-and-connector" topological connections, and this topological analysis inspired chemists to assemble coordination polymers from the assumed building blocks (nodes) in a reciprocal way. Such a hypothetical synthesis, in principle, is very helpful to predict and design target coordination frameworks; nevertheless, the details in how the building blocks are polymerized during crystallization remain largely unknown. On the contrary, a number of excellent solution dynamics studies have been carried out to elucidate the assembly processes for discrete molecular architectures.

elements.content: One common phenomenon of structural diversity occurring in coordination polymers is so-called supramolecular isomerism, known as conformation isomerism, structural isomerism, topological isomerism, and so on. Supramolecular isomerism occurring between the finite ring and the polymeric chain has been observed by us and others, and was termed as ring-opening isomerism. This structural relationship may give us a clue to explore the structural conversion between the discrete cyclic structures and the infinite polymeric structures, thus to understand the assembly mechanism of the coordination polymers. A number of interesting systems have been investigated to show ring-opening polymerization of the cyclic or cage precursors, which was believed to be the reason why polymeric structures could be formed. The ligands used in these studies were normally monodentate, and the M2L2 metallacycles were often the thermodynamically favored solution motifs due to the ligand conformation and steric interference. Herein, we report a series of Ag(I) complexes based on a flexible bis-bidentate ligand C4TQ (C4TQ = 1,4-bis(8-thioquinolyl)butane), namely, [Ag2(C4TQ)2](CF3SO3)2 (1), {[Ag(C4TQ)](CF3SO3)} n ·0.5nCH3CN (2), [Ag2(C4TQ)2](ClO4)2 (3), {[Ag(C4TQ)](ClO4)} n (4), and {[Ag(C4TQ)(CH3CN)](ClO4)} n (5). The flexibility of the ligand allowed formation of potential ML monomers in solution, which can dimerize to offer M2L2 cyclic structures in 1 and 3 while polymerize to offer M n L n infinite structures in 2 and 4. This indicated a structural isomerization process during the crystallization, which was supported by solution 1H NMR and electrospray ionization mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) investigations, solid-state X-ray diffraction (XRD) studies, and density functional theory calculations. The complex 4 has already been reported previously but is mentioned in this paper for comparison.

elements.content: All chemicals were of reagent grade from commercial sources and used without further purification. The C, H, N analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker EQUINOX55 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr discs in the 4000–400 cm−1 region. ESI-MS was performed on a Thermo Finigan LCQDECA XP ion trap mass spectrometer. XRD patterns were acquired on a Rigaku D/Max-2200 powder X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). The ligand C4TQ was prepared according to a previously described method.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Methods

All chemicals were of reagent grade from commercial sources and used without further purification. The C, H, N analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Bruker EQUINOX55 FT-IR spectrophotometer using KBr discs in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. ESI-MS was performed on a Thermo Finigan LCQDECA XP ion trap mass spectrometer. XRD patterns were acquired on a Rigaku D/Max-2200 powder X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromatized Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15418 nm). The ligand C4TQ was prepared according to a previously described method.

elements.content: Although we have not encountered any problem in handling perchlorate salts and their complexes during this work, these compounds should be treated with great caution owing to their potentially explosive nature.
elements.clean_text:
Caution

Although we have not encountered any problem in handling perchlorate salts and their complexes during this work, these compounds should be treated with great caution owing to their potentially explosive nature.

elements.content: All the complexes were prepared by a similar procedure. A solution of AgX (0.1 mmol, X = CF3SO3 − or ClO4 −) in CH3CN (2–4 mL) was added dropwise to a stirred solution of C4TQ (37.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) in CHCl3 (2–4 mL). Slow diffusion of Et2O into the resulting solution yielded colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis. Complexes 2 and 4 can also be obtained by direct addition of Et2O into the reaction mixtures, resulting in relatively rapid precipitation of the complexes.
elements.clean_text:
Complexes Synthesis

All the complexes were prepared by a similar procedure. A solution of AgX (0.1 mmol, X = CF3SO3 - or ClO4 -) in CH3CN (2-4 mL) was added dropwise to a stirred solution of C4TQ (37.6 mg, 0.1 mmol) in CHCl3 (2-4 mL). Slow diffusion of Et2O into the resulting solution yielded colorless single crystals suitable for X-ray analysis. Complexes 2 and 4 can also be obtained by direct addition of Et2O into the reaction mixtures, resulting in relatively rapid precipitation of the complexes.

Yield 63%. IR (cm−1, KBr): 3051w, 2930w, 2857w, 1595w, 1561w, 1493m, 1455w, 1430w, 1367w, 1308m, 1201w, 1087s, 986m, 830m, 787m, 692w, 667w, 621m.

X-ray Crystallography

Experimental details of the X-ray structural analysis as well as the crystallographic data are provided in Table . Selected bond distances and angles are listed in Table . The diffraction data were collected on a Bruker Smart 1K CCD diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at room temperature. The diffractometer was run with the program SMART, and the data were processed by SAINT+. Absorption corrections were applied with SADABS program. The structures were solved by the direct methods (SHELXS) and refined by the full-matrix least-squares method against F o 2 using SHELXTL software. The coordinates of most non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. All hydrogen atoms were introduced in calculated positions and refined with fixed geometry with respect to their carrier atoms. The CF3 group of the CF3SO3 − anion in complex 2 showed disorder with F atoms occupying two positions. The solvated MeCN molecule was also disordered over two positions. The alkyl chain of the C4TQ ligand in complex 3 showed disorder with the two central C atoms located in two different sites, and the ClO4 − displayed severe disorder showing multiply atom locations. All these disordered atoms were treated with fractional occupancy. Some of them were refined isotropically due to bad displacement parameters.

All calculations were performed with the Gaussian 03 software package on a Pentium IV computer, using the default convergence criteria. The visualization software GaussView has generated the view of the computing models and the frontier molecular orbitals. Self-consistent DFT calculations were performed using the B3LYP density functional in both the gas phase and MeCN solvent. In terms of disk space, computer time and the size of the molecules studied here, the standard 6-31G basis set was used for the lighter atoms and LANL2DZ was used for the silver atoms.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

All calculations were performed with the Gaussian 03 software package on a Pentium IV computer, using the default convergence criteria. The visualization software GaussView has generated the view of the computing models and the frontier molecular orbitals. Self-consistent DFT calculations were performed using the B3LYP density functional in both the gas phase and MeCN solvent. In terms of disk space, computer time and the size of the molecules studied here, the standard 6-31G basis set was used for the lighter atoms and LANL2DZ was used for the silver atoms.

elements.content: As seen from , all the complexes were obtained under a quite similar reaction condition. It was found that slow crystal growth upon diffusion of Et2O into the reaction mixture afforded pure product in most cases. However, the structure of the product seemed to largely depend on the concentration of the reaction mixture. In general, when 4 mL of respective MeCN and CHCl3 was used, the dinuclear cyclic complexes 1 and 3 were obtained, while the use of less MeCN/CHCl3 mixture (2/2 mL) was in favor of formation of polymeric complexes 2 and 4. In addition, rapid precipitation of complexes by direct addition of Et2O into the reaction mixture resulted in formation of 2 and 4, but too fast precipitation usually gave rise to impure products. These observations indicated that formation of the cyclic structures was preferred in dilute reaction solution with slow crystallization speed. With the opposite conditions, the polymeric structure was preferred. It is evident that there is a subtle balance between the cyclic and polymeric structures, and the crystallization condition of each structure can be easily affected. This makes it difficult to control the synthesis of each complex; however, once a smooth crystallization occurs, relatively pure product can be obtained. Complex 5 was occasionally obtained, and reproducible preparation seems out of control. The anions in all the complexes were confirmed by IR measurements, and the molecular structures have been unequivocally determined by X-ray single crystal analyses.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses and Characterization

As seen from , all the complexes were obtained under a quite similar reaction condition. It was found that slow crystal growth upon diffusion of Et2O into the reaction mixture afforded pure product in most cases. However, the structure of the product seemed to largely depend on the concentration of the reaction mixture. In general, when 4 mL of respective MeCN and CHCl3 was used, the dinuclear cyclic complexes 1 and 3 were obtained, while the use of less MeCN/CHCl3 mixture (2/2 mL) was in favor of formation of polymeric complexes 2 and 4. In addition, rapid precipitation of complexes by direct addition of Et2O into the reaction mixture resulted in formation of 2 and 4, but too fast precipitation usually gave rise to impure products. These observations indicated that formation of the cyclic structures was preferred in dilute reaction solution with slow crystallization speed. With the opposite conditions, the polymeric structure was preferred. It is evident that there is a subtle balance between the cyclic and polymeric structures, and the crystallization condition of each structure can be easily affected. This makes it difficult to control the synthesis of each complex; however, once a smooth crystallization occurs, relatively pure product can be obtained. Complex 5 was occasionally obtained, and reproducible preparation seems out of control. The anions in all the complexes were confirmed by IR measurements, and the molecular structures have been unequivocally determined by X-ray single crystal analyses.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, complex 1 displays a discrete disilver(I) metallacyclic framework, composed of one [Ag2(C4TQ)2]2+ cation and two uncoordinated CF3SO3 − anions. Each Ag(I) center lies in a distorted tetrahedral environment, chelated by two thioquinoline rings from two different C4TQ ligands through the sulfur and nitrogen donors. The CF3SO3 − anions are located at two sides of the M2L2 metallacycle, forming weak C−H···O interactions. All quinoline rings of the [Ag2(C4TQ)2]2+ metallacycles are involved in formation of offset intermolecular π−π stacking with the centroid-to-centroid distances falling in the range of 3.60–3.72 Å, which further assembles the macrocycles into a 3D supramolecular network as shown in Figure b.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structures and Packing

As shown in Figure a, complex 1 displays a discrete disilver(I) metallacyclic framework, composed of one [Ag2(C4TQ)2]2+ cation and two uncoordinated CF3SO3 - anions. Each Ag(I) center lies in a distorted tetrahedral environment, chelated by two thioquinoline rings from two different C4TQ ligands through the sulfur and nitrogen donors. The CF3SO3 - anions are located at two sides of the M2L2 metallacycle, forming weak C-H⋅⋅⋅O interactions. All quinoline rings of the [Ag2(C4TQ)2]2+ metallacycles are involved in formation of offset intermolecular π-π stacking with the centroid-to-centroid distances falling in the range of 3.60-3.72 Å, which further assembles the macrocycles into a 3D supramolecular network as shown in Figure b.

elements.content: (a) The discrete dinuclear M2L2 cationic structure and (b) their π−π stacking in complex 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) The discrete dinuclear M2L2 cationic structure and (b) their π-π stacking in complex 1.

elements.content: By contrast, complex 2 exhibits a polymeric 1D structure. The cationic framework is shown in Figure . Each Ag(I) ion has a similar distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry with two S and two N donors coming from two different C4TQ ligands. In comparison to the M2L2 metallacycle in 1, the C4TQ ligands in 2 join the Ag(I) ions in a head-to-tail fashion to form an infinite 1D zigzag chain extending along the c axis. The CF3SO3 − anions are also uncoordinated, locating in between the chains by forming weak C−H···O hydrogen bonds. It is noticeable that the weak Ag···S interactions (3.67 Å) in 2 join two 1D chains to form a double-chain as depicted in Figure a. The two quinoline rings (TQ) of the same C4TQ ligand are almost perpendicular to each other (dihedral angle 87.8°), and the two TQ rings coordinated with the same silver(I) ion are also perpendicular to each other (dihedral angle 89.0°), thus providing potential supramolecular recognition sites for π−π aromatic stacking in four directions (Figure b). As shown in Figure c, every two adjacent double-chains are zippered together by interdigitating TQ rings via multiple offset intermolecular π−π interactions (centroid-to-centroid distances 3.74–3.94 Å); therefore, every double-chain interacts with four neighbors to sustain the 3D crystal packing.

elements.content: Single crystal diffraction revealed that complex 3 was a discrete dinuclear M2L2 structure (Figure a) similar to that of 1. The Ag(I) ions are in a distorted tetrahedral coordination geometry with Ag−S and Ag−N bond distances comparable with those of 1; however, the crystal packing is significantly different from that in 1. As shown in Figure b, each M2L2 metallacycle interacts with four neighbors via π···π stacking (centroid-to-centroid distances 3.74–3.94 Å), resulting in a 2D brick-wall packing layer in the ab plane. The ClO4 − anions are located in between the layers. Such a different crystal packing fashion in 1 and 3 may be caused by different shapes of the counteranions.

elements.content: The crystal structure of complex 4 has been described in ref , which displays a 1D chain similar to that in complex 2. It is interesting that complex 5 was obtained unexpectedly under essentially the same crystallizing condition of 4. The crystal structural analysis revealed a different 1D chain structure with the MeCN molecule participating in coordination. As shown in Figure a, the silver(I) ion still adopted a distorted AgN2S2 tetrahedral coordination geometry, but one nitrogen donor of TQ ring in complex 4 was replaced by acetonitrile nitrogen atom in complex 5. Therefore, the C4TQ ligand in complex 5 exhibited two coordination modes: one is bis-bidentate, while the other is bis-monodentate (Figure b). These two types of ligands connect the Ag(I) ions alternately to result in an infinite chain. The two TQ rings coordinating with the same Ag(I) ion are nearly coplanar (dihedral angles 12.6°), forming intramolecular π···π stacking with the centroid-to-centroid distance in the range of 3.83–3.95 Å. Furthermore, the intermolecular π···π interactions (centroid-to-centroid distances 3.90–3.97 Å) are formed between the 1D chains, which link the 1D chains into 2D layer as depicted in Figure c. The ClO4 − anions are uncoordinated, locating in between the layers.

elements.content: Since all complexes crystallized under quite similar conditions but exhibited apparently distinctive structures, inherent structural relationships and potential structural conversion may exist among these structures when crystallizing. It is obvious that the coordination frameworks of cyclic complexes 1 and 3 can be simplified as M2L2, and those of polymeric complexes 2 and 4 as M n L n . All of them have the same metal-to-ligand ratio of 1:1 and a similar tetrahedral coordination geometry. If the charge balance anions are considered but the solvated MeCN molecules in complex 2 are neglected, two pairs of isomeric structures, [Ag2(C4TQ)2](CF3SO3)2 vs {[Ag(C4TQ)](CF3SO3)} n in complexes 1 and 2, as well as [Ag2(C4TQ)2](Cl4)2 vs {[Ag(C4TQ)](ClO4)} n in complexes 3 and 4, respectively, can be identified. We can call them “ring-opening isomers” which directly express the structural relationship between the cyclic and polymeric complexes. On the other hand, if we simply consider that the cyclic M2L2 and polymeric M n L n structures are assembled from the same monomeric building blocks by ignoring the contributions of the solvents and counteranions, formation of the different coordination frameworks from the same monomers can be regarded as a structural isomerization procedure, similar to the isomeric structures reported in the mixed-metal clusters and inclusion frameworks without considering the solvents and guest molecules. However, a detailed solution structure study suggests that the assembly mechanism involves a solvent and/or anion assisted ligand exchange process.
elements.clean_text:
Solution Structure and Assembly Mechanism

Since all complexes crystallized under quite similar conditions but exhibited apparently distinctive structures, inherent structural relationships and potential structural conversion may exist among these structures when crystallizing. It is obvious that the coordination frameworks of cyclic complexes 1 and 3 can be simplified as M2L2, and those of polymeric complexes 2 and 4 as M n L n . All of them have the same metal-to-ligand ratio of 1:1 and a similar tetrahedral coordination geometry. If the charge balance anions are considered but the solvated MeCN molecules in complex 2 are neglected, two pairs of isomeric structures, [Ag2(C4TQ)2](CF3SO3)2 vs {[Ag(C4TQ)](CF3SO3)} n  in complexes 1 and 2, as well as [Ag2(C4TQ)2](Cl4)2 vs {[Ag(C4TQ)](ClO4)} n  in complexes 3 and 4, respectively, can be identified. We can call them "ring-opening isomers" which directly express the structural relationship between the cyclic and polymeric complexes. On the other hand, if we simply consider that the cyclic M2L2 and polymeric M n L n  structures are assembled from the same monomeric building blocks by ignoring the contributions of the solvents and counteranions, formation of the different coordination frameworks from the same monomers can be regarded as a structural isomerization procedure, similar to the isomeric structures reported in the mixed-metal clusters and inclusion frameworks without considering the solvents and guest molecules. However, a detailed solution structure study suggests that the assembly mechanism involves a solvent and/or anion assisted ligand exchange process.

elements.content: It is usually assumed that the assembly of the coordination framework starts from the smallest building blocks. Therefore, possible routes to form the cationic frameworks of complexes 1–4 may be represented by Scheme . That is, the ML monomers are initially formed in solution, which can dimerize to give M2L2 metallacycle or polymerize to give M n L n polymer upon crystallization. Since C4TQ contains a long flexible (CH2)4 alkyl chain and behaves as a bis-bidentate ligand, formation of ML monomer is expectable. Two TQ rings can chelate the same Ag(I) ion to offer a tetrahedral coordination geometry similar to those in complexes 1–4 (see DFT calculations below). To gain evidence supporting this hypothesis, 1H NMR and ESI-MS investigations have been carried out for complexes 1 and 2. As shown in Figure , the NMR spectra of 1 and 2 measured immediately after dissolving crystal samples displayed remarkably different signal profiles: only one set of signals for 2 (Figure b) while two sets of signals for 1 (Figure c). All proton signals were down field shifted compared to those of the “free” ligand (Figure e), indicating that these signals are attributable to coordination species existing in solution due to an inductive effect of metal ions upon complexation. The polymeric complex 2 may be expected to degrade to monomers, or linear or cyclic oligomers in solution by the aid of solvent and/or anion interactions. The rapid metal–ligand exchange could result in the appearance of one set of signals if a fast equilibrium was established among these kinetically labile species, but broadening of some signals denoted that such structural conversions may take a while to achieve the equilibrium. On the contrary, two sets of signals appeared for complex 1, of which one set resembles those peaks of the complex 2, while the other set may stem from the DMSO-solvated dimer. This observation suggested that the M2L2 cyclic species also degraded when it was dissolved, but the structural conversion was not fast enough and thus detectable in the NMR time scale along with signal broadening. Therefore, the M2L2 cyclic structure may not be the thermodynamically most stable species in solution. For a comparison, 1H NMR spectrum was recorded by direct mixing AgCF3SO3 and C4TQ in a 1:1 ratio in DMSO solution (Figure d), which gave rise to a signal pattern closely similar to that of complexes 2 and one of the two sets signals of complex 1. However, the proton peaks were well resolved in contrast to the broadened signals of the dissolved crystalline samples. From this comparison we can speculate that the degradation of M2L2 and M n L n frameworks will lead to immediate structural conversions, but these conversions need a while to reach the equilibrium that can be achieved faster by direct reaction of free Ag(I) ion and C4TQ ligand. The solvent and/or anion molecules may be involved in the structural conversions to facilitate facile ligand exchange and minimize the energy barriers of the intermediate species. When the samples were measured one day later, identical spectra were obtained for both complexes 1 and 2 (Figure a), suggesting that such structural conversions starting from different complexes finally reach the same equilibrium.

elements.content: To further elucidate the solution structures, ESI-MS measurements were performed by mixing AgCF3SO3 and C4TQ in a 1:1 ratio in methanol. As shown in Figure , the spectrum exhibits a major peak at m/z 485 assignable to the monomeric [Ag(C4TQ)]+ species. In addition, there are two small peaks at m/z 741 and 1118 that correspond to the disilver(I) M2L motif ({Ag2(C4TQ)](CF3SO3)}+) and cyclic M2L2 motif ({Ag2(C4TQ)2](CF3SO3)}+), respectively. These observations may indicate that, in solution, different solution species are indeed present, among which the ML monomer is dominant over the M2L2 dimers and other undetectable potential oligomers. The ML monomer could convert to the M2L motif by releasing one chelate TQ ring to bind the second metal ion. Anions and solvents (not detected in the ESI-MS spectrum) may serve as auxiliary ligands to facilitate such conversion.

elements.content: The above NMR and ESI-MS studies are in agreement with the hypothesis that the ML monomers can act as initial precursors for formation of the cyclic and polymeric structures. Taking into consideration the thermodynamic effect, the ML monomer represents the smallest possible coordination motif that can utilize all the coordination donors of C4TQ, thus being the thermodynamically most-favored species due to maximum enthalpy gain with a minimum possible entropy loss. This situation is in contrast to that observed for the Ag(I) complexes with various ditopic nonchelating ligands, where the M2L2dimer represents the smallest cyclic structure thus predominating in solution. Therefore, dissolution of either cyclic or polymeric complexes will lead to degradation of the coordination frameworks to the thermodynamically stable ML monomers. On the contrary, upon crystallization, the ML monomers can dimerize or polymerize to convert to the M2L2 dimer or the M n L n polymer, respectively, as shown in Scheme . This process can be regarded as a structural isomerization that takes place during crystallization and largely depends on the subtle thermodynamic and kinetic influences under crystallization conditions. It is generally believed that the cyclic structures are preferred over the chain structures for enthalpic reasons, while the small M2L2 metallacycles are favored over larger ones (at low concentration) for entropic reasons. However, the energy difference between the cyclic and the polymeric structures may be quite small, which can be easily affected by various external influences that can convert the equilibrium to a certain structure. Although both cyclic and polymeric structures are kinetic products, the cyclic complexes 1 and 3 may be more thermodynamically preferred, while the polymeric 2 and 4 may be more kinetically preferred. This assumption is consistent with the observations described in .
elements.clean_text: The above NMR and ESI-MS studies are in agreement with the hypothesis that the ML monomers can act as initial precursors for formation of the cyclic and polymeric structures. Taking into consideration the thermodynamic effect, the ML monomer represents the smallest possible coordination motif that can utilize all the coordination donors of C4TQ, thus being the thermodynamically most-favored species due to maximum enthalpy gain with a minimum possible entropy loss. This situation is in contrast to that observed for the Ag(I) complexes with various ditopic nonchelating ligands, where the M2L2dimer represents the smallest cyclic structure thus predominating in solution. Therefore, dissolution of either cyclic or polymeric complexes will lead to degradation of the coordination frameworks to the thermodynamically stable ML monomers. On the contrary, upon crystallization, the ML monomers can dimerize or polymerize to convert to the M2L2 dimer or the M n L n  polymer, respectively, as shown in Scheme . This process can be regarded as a structural isomerization that takes place during crystallization and largely depends on the subtle thermodynamic and kinetic influences under crystallization conditions. It is generally believed that the cyclic structures are preferred over the chain structures for enthalpic reasons, while the small M2L2 metallacycles are favored over larger ones (at low concentration) for entropic reasons. However, the energy difference between the cyclic and the polymeric structures may be quite small, which can be easily affected by various external influences that can convert the equilibrium to a certain structure. Although both cyclic and polymeric structures are kinetic products, the cyclic complexes 1 and 3 may be more thermodynamically preferred, while the polymeric 2 and 4 may be more kinetically preferred. This assumption is consistent with the observations described in .

elements.content: To understand the roles played by the solvent and anion molecules during the structural conversion, it is worthwhile to compare the chain framework in complex 5 with those in 2 and 4. One MeCN molecule coordinates to Ag(I) ion in 5 to replace one N donor from the TQ ring in 2 and 4. This observation may suggest that the assembly processes from ML monomers to M2L2 dimers or M n L n polymers involve contributions from solvent or anion molecules (simplified as X). As shown in Scheme , the onset of small X molecules to a monomer (I) helps to release one chelate TQ ring (in II) which becomes free to interact with the second Ag(I) ion (in III). Further reaction of intermediate III with the second C4TQ ligand proceeds via sequentially replacing X molecules by the TQ ring. Once all X molecules are replaced, complexes 1–4 will be formed depending on the subtle thermodynamic and kinetic balance achieved upon crystallization. This is the normal case because the TQ ring provides two chelating donors to complete the coordination geometry of the metal center. Therefore, the MeCN molecules in complex 2 stay in the crystal lattice without participating in coordination. In the case of a specific crystallization condition where X molecules could not be completely replaced, intermediate IV may be formed, which can polymerize to result in complex 5 retaining one binding MeCN molecule. Therefore, crystallization of complex 5 may reflect an intermediate procedure during the structural conversion. Isolation of this complex provides valuable evidence to confirm the solvent and/or anion assisted assembly mechanism speculated from the above solution study.

elements.content: The XRD analyses have been used to check the phase purity of the bulky products obtained under different crystallization conditions. Figure shows the measured XRD patterns of complexes 1, 2 and their simulated powder patterns on the basis of the single-crystal analyses results. It is obvious that the measured pattern of complex 2 matches the simulated one very well, indicative of a pure product. Most of the salient peaks in the measured pattern of complex 1 also correspond to the simulated peaks. However, there are a few peaks that do not match the simulated pattern of 1 but may correspond to those found in the simulated pattern of 2. These findings indicate that the bulky sample of complex 1 contains a little portion of complex 2, suggesting a concomitant crystallization of 2, although most of the products are crystallized as 1. We further dissolved the bulky sample of 1 in DMSO and precipitated the product rapidly by addition of Et2O. The XRD pattern recorded for the thus obtained solid was closely similar to the measured pattern of 2 as seen from Figure c, clearly indicating that the complex 1 has been converted to complex 2 upon fast recrystallization. This result confirmed that the structural conversion happened when complex 1 was dissolved, and such structural conversion was largely dependent on the crystallization condition, in agreement with the results of NMR and ESI-MS investigations.
elements.clean_text:
Phase Purity and Structural Conversion

The XRD analyses have been used to check the phase purity of the bulky products obtained under different crystallization conditions. Figure  shows the measured XRD patterns of complexes 1, 2 and their simulated powder patterns on the basis of the single-crystal analyses results. It is obvious that the measured pattern of complex 2 matches the simulated one very well, indicative of a pure product. Most of the salient peaks in the measured pattern of complex 1 also correspond to the simulated peaks. However, there are a few peaks that do not match the simulated pattern of 1 but may correspond to those found in the simulated pattern of 2. These findings indicate that the bulky sample of complex 1 contains a little portion of complex 2, suggesting a concomitant crystallization of 2, although most of the products are crystallized as 1. We further dissolved the bulky sample of 1 in DMSO and precipitated the product rapidly by addition of Et2O. The XRD pattern recorded for the thus obtained solid was closely similar to the measured pattern of 2 as seen from Figure c, clearly indicating that the complex 1 has been converted to complex 2 upon fast recrystallization. This result confirmed that the structural conversion happened when complex 1 was dissolved, and such structural conversion was largely dependent on the crystallization condition, in agreement with the results of NMR and ESI-MS investigations.

elements.content: To obtain more evidence concerning the question of whether the ML monomer is the thermodynamic species and potential precursor for formation of the cyclic and polymeric structures, preliminary DFT calculations were performed based on the monomeric ML model from MM2 calculations and the dimeric M2L2 motif from the X-ray crystal determination. Figure illustrates the frontier molecular orbitals of the optimized ML monomer and M2L2 dimmer, and Table lists their energies and characteristic dihedral angles. The calculation indicates that in the gas phase, the monomeric model does converge to an optimized mononuclear unit which has lower energy than that of the dinuclear unit. To transfer from the monomer to the dimer, an energy of 97 kJ/mol is needed. This value is surprisingly large for a facile direct structural conversion; however, after we took into consideration the MeCN solvent effect, the energy disparity between the mononuclear and the dinuclear units interconverts, with the latter one 23 kJ/mol lower than twice of the former. This DFT calculation result concerning the solvent effect indeed shows the significant energy adjustment by considering solvent molecules in the assembly process, which confirms our speculation as discussed above that the structural conversions from the ML monomers to the M2L2 dimer or M n L n polymer may be assisted by solvent and/or anion participation. The calculated 23 kJ/mol is a favorable energy gap for the structure to convert easily from one unit to another. In addition, the optimized structures of the dimeric M2L2 motif shows some conformational difference to those observed in the crystal structures of 1 and 3, suggesting that the crystal packing may also contribute to stabilize the kinetic products.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

To obtain more evidence concerning the question of whether the ML monomer is the thermodynamic species and potential precursor for formation of the cyclic and polymeric structures, preliminary DFT calculations were performed based on the monomeric ML model from MM2 calculations and the dimeric M2L2 motif from the X-ray crystal determination. Figure  illustrates the frontier molecular orbitals of the optimized ML monomer and M2L2 dimmer, and Table  lists their energies and characteristic dihedral angles. The calculation indicates that in the gas phase, the monomeric model does converge to an optimized mononuclear unit which has lower energy than that of the dinuclear unit. To transfer from the monomer to the dimer, an energy of 97 kJ/mol is needed. This value is surprisingly large for a facile direct structural conversion; however, after we took into consideration the MeCN solvent effect, the energy disparity between the mononuclear and the dinuclear units interconverts, with the latter one 23 kJ/mol lower than twice of the former. This DFT calculation result concerning the solvent effect indeed shows the significant energy adjustment by considering solvent molecules in the assembly process, which confirms our speculation as discussed above that the structural conversions from the ML monomers to the M2L2 dimer or M n L n  polymer may be assisted by solvent and/or anion participation. The calculated 23 kJ/mol is a favorable energy gap for the structure to convert easily from one unit to another. In addition, the optimized structures of the dimeric M2L2 motif shows some conformational difference to those observed in the crystal structures of 1 and 3, suggesting that the crystal packing may also contribute to stabilize the kinetic products.

The four C atoms on the butyl chain.

Five Ag(I) complexes have been assembled from a flexible ligand 1,4-bis(thioquinolyl)butane (C4TQ) and different silver(I) salts, which display close structural relationships between the finite and infinite coordination frameworks. Two pairs of ring-opening isomers can be identified from complexes 1, 2 and 3, 4, respectively. These isomers may be formed via a solvent and/or anion assisted assembly process during crystallization. That is, the ML monomers dimerize to lead to a cyclic M2L2 framework while polymerize to lead to a M n L n framework. Isolation of complex 5 confirms that such structural conversion proceeds by the aid of small solvent or anion molecules. 1H NMR, ESI-MS, and XRD measurements have been carried out to elucidate the solution dynamics and structural conversions upon dissolution and crystallization, which are in accord with the above speculated assembly mechanism and supported by DFT calculations.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Five Ag(I) complexes have been assembled from a flexible ligand 1,4-bis(thioquinolyl)butane (C4TQ) and different silver(I) salts, which display close structural relationships between the finite and infinite coordination frameworks. Two pairs of ring-opening isomers can be identified from complexes 1, 2 and 3, 4, respectively. These isomers may be formed via a solvent and/or anion assisted assembly process during crystallization. That is, the ML monomers dimerize to lead to a cyclic M2L2 framework while polymerize to lead to a M n L n  framework. Isolation of complex 5 confirms that such structural conversion proceeds by the aid of small solvent or anion molecules. 1H NMR, ESI-MS, and XRD measurements have been carried out to elucidate the solution dynamics and structural conversions upon dissolution and crystallization, which are in accord with the above speculated assembly mechanism and supported by DFT calculations.
